definition:
The Jacobi identity in a Lie algebra $\mathfrak{g}$ has various
interpretations that are more transparent, whence easier to remember,
than the usual form $$[x,[y,z]]+[y,[z,x]]+[z,[x,y]]=0.$$ One is the fact
that the adjoint representation [^1]
${\operatorname{ad}}:\mathfrak{g} \rightarrow \mathfrak{gl}(\mathfrak{g})$
really is a representation. Yet another way to formulate the identity is
$${\operatorname{ad}}(x)[y,z]=[{\operatorname{ad}}(x)y,z]+[y,{\operatorname{ad}}(x)z],$$
i.e., ${\operatorname{ad}}(x)$ is a derivation on $\mathfrak{g}$ for all
$x \in \mathfrak{g}$.

[^1]: Here, “$\mathfrak{gl}(\mathfrak{g})$” means the space o
    endomorphisms of $\mathfrak{g}$, viewed as a vector space, with Lie
    bracket on $\mathfrak{gl}(\mathfrak{g})$being commutator.
